Detailed Description

Write a JPEG image to file using libjpeg.

Thread-safe if multiple threads do not access the same JPEGWriter at once. Writes directly from the caller's memory, minimizing copying.

Member Function Documentation

void JPEGWriter::setQuality (  const unsigned  value,
const bool  forceBaseline = false
)  [inline]
 

Set the quality setting, in the range of zero (lowest) to 100 (highest).

If forceBaseline is true, then compatibility with different JPEG readers is increased at the expense of increased file size of very-low quality (under 25) images.

const std::string & JPEGWriter::warnings (   )  const [inline]
 

Get warnings generated by libjpeg since the last call to header().

Separate warnings are separated by a newline.

template<typename RowPtrIter>
void JPEGWriter::write (  const std::string &  path,
RowPtrIter  rows
) 
 

Write a JPEG image given by the row iterator rows to the file at path.

A RowPtrIter should act basically like an unsigned char**:

  • It must dereference to the start of a chunk of memory at least width * components bytes long.
  • It should be incrementable height times.
  • It will be pre-incremented immediately after each row is written out.

Normal pointers, iterators into a std::vector<unsigned char*>, and related things will all work as you expect.

A normal usage would be something like: 

        writer.header(width, height, 3, JPEG::COLOR_RGB);
        unsigned char** rows = new unsigned char*[height];
        for (int i = 0; i < height; ++i)
            rows[i] = new unsigned char[width];
        writer.write("myfile.jpg", rows);
Of course, the equivalent code using std::vector is highly recommended.

If you have only a row at a time, then something like the following will also work and be more efficient: 

        struct InputRowIter {
            InputRowIter(some input source, const unsigned size):
                buffer(size) {
                ... fill the buffer with one row's worth of pixels ...
            }
       
            unsigned char* operator*() {
                return &buffer[0];
            }
            
            void operator++() {
                ... fill the buffer with one row's worth of pixels ...
            }
            
            std::vector<unsigned char> buffer;
        };
        
        InputRowIter rowIter(some input source, width * components);
        writer.header(width, height, 3, JPEG::COLOR_RGB);
        writer.write("myfile.jpg", rowIter);
